video.title: South Park: Snow Day! | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
The final novel in my Jacques McKeown 
trilogy, Will Leave the Galaxy for Good,

is now available on audible.com. Tell 
them Yahtzee sent ya. They won&#39;t care.
Second Wind
[Intro Music]

I don&#39;t want to get drawn into another tiresome 
argument over whether South Park is still or was

ever good. Sure, its habit of aloofly dismissing 
both sides of most societal issues as quote &quot;gay&quot;,

It comes across as a little
tone deaf in the day and age

and as the work of a bunch of detached rich 
manchildren who clearly don&#39;t have enough

problems in life, but it was a product 
of that pre 9-11 pre financial crisis era

when American society in general didn&#39;t 
have enough problems in life and there&#39;s

something to be admired in its consistency - 
er, sorry Yahtz, I was actually just asking

if South Park Snow Day is any good. Oh. No, 
it sucks balls. And it&#39;s gay. Oh my goodness!

He said it! Bet that&#39;ll trigger a few of those 
spoilsport parents of school shooting victims,

cry laughing emoji. Was that all? Well, thanks 
for dropping by. Could you put the door back on

its hinges on your way out? The South Park games, 
then, which officially started with South Park:

The Stick of Truth in 2014 and if anyone tries 
to tell you there were South Park games before

that they&#39;re lying and you should chase them 
from their homes with guns and attack dogs.

Stick of Truth, or to use its full title, the 
surprisingly better than it had any right to

be Stick of Truth was a 2D turn-based RPG that 
played like an interactive episode of the show.

Its sequel Fractured But Whole for me suffered 
from leaning on inside references too much and

not really building upon its predecessor where 
the nuts and bolts were concerned, but as I was

trying to say earlier, there is something to 
be said for staying consistent - Consistency,

Yahtz? No! That&#39;s gay. Yeah, I said it again, 
cry some more, The Guardian. We&#39;re going to

completely mix things up by making Snow Day a 
full 3D game. Oh. With real time combat. Ohhhh.

And a focus on co-op multiplayer. Ohhhhhhhhhh. 
Yahtz, stop incrementing random vowels. I can&#39;t

help it. An established single player franchise 
suddenly pulling out a co-op focussed sequel is

one of the leadups to armageddon in the Book 
of Revelations, just between war in the middle

east and the election of the Antichrist. And 
anyway, the real strength of the South Park

games is the way the show&#39;s creators are 
hands on with them, so they benefit from

authentic witty dialogue, please specify 
your preference for size of sarcasm quotes.

But as many a Spider-Man game can attest, 
the marriage of witty dialogue and real time

combat does not make for wet patches on the 
bedsheet. Turn-based combat gave the last two

games a reliable pace with plenty of pauses into 
which verbal gags could more happily be inserted,

in real time you tend to end up hearing the 
same lines over and over again, with all comic

timing lost as the punchline is drowned out by an 
ill-timed crunch of punished testicles. So with

Snow Day South Park is throwing away its major 
strength right off the bat, and then there&#39;s the

fact that, while the deliberately lazy paper cut 
out visual style might be very effective at both

conveying the mood of an irreverent crude cartoon 
show and irritating Mr. Jefferies the art teacher,

as a vehicle for real time combat then surely 
it would be too difficult to read. Once you

go past a certain degree of stylisation an 
NPC could be launching towards you for an

affectionate cuddle or to push your eyeballs 
out through the back of your skull. I mean,

MY visual style works well enough to deliver 
gags and is easy to knock out during my brief

windows of consciousness but I wouldn&#39;t 
use it for a combat engine &#39;cos there&#39;s

no visual difference between a character 
winding up a punch and saluting a Nazi.

So even sight unseen I had my misgivings about a 
full 3D real time combat based South Park game,

remember the terrible N64 ga - I mean don&#39;t 
remember it because it didn&#39;t exist. But even

I was surprised by how many layers of dogshit 
awaited me in Snow Day like extremely suspect

puff pastry. The plot is, a freak snowstorm hits 
South Park and all the kids are off school doing

that townwide LARP from the first game, and you 
once again take up the mantle of The New Kid to

help unite the main characters and their 
armies against the common threat and end

the endless winter, blurring of reality 
and fantasy, COVID lockdown references,

slightly sophomoric fixation on poo poos, blah de 
blah de blah. Or perhaps I should say New Kids,

plural, that&#39;s how you can tell it&#39;s co-op 
focussed, &#39;cos everyone seems to have gotten

the wrong kind of snowblind and keeps talking 
like there&#39;s more than one of you. This always

annoys me because it puts a game&#39;s narrative 
element on the wrong foot. I&#39;m special,

damn it. I&#39;m a super special boy who will do great 
things and possesses basic sentience and can pull

off facial hair really well. I know, &#39;cos my 
mum told me. And I demand to be treated as such.

But while the New Kid in the previous games was a 
protagonist and leader, in Snow Day they more take

the role of hatchet man and town bitch while 
only the established characters are allowed

to actually participate in what story can be 
injected between the tedious slugfests like

intramuscular steroids. In the final mission, 
it&#39;s the four leads who identify the villain,

try to reason with them, realise that only a 
final climactic encounter will save the town,

and as the cutscene fades out they turn to the 
New Kid and all but word for word say &quot;Right,

now you go do the boring part.&quot; The New Kid is 
excised altogether from the ending cinematic,

presumably they&#39;re busy offscreen having an 
extremely heated phone call with their agent. Oh,

and when I say final mission, I mean mission 
five. That&#39;s all you get. Although that might

be for the best since they&#39;ve run out of ideas 
by mission two. Who&#39;d have thought that a game

about fighting off hordes of identical champagne 
corks exclusively in outdoor snowy environments

would struggle to be visually interesting? Oh and 
of course combat is hard to read and looks like

a heated argument taking place in a punnet 
of button mushrooms. That much I expected.

I didn&#39;t expect the interface to be so crap 
as well, all default Windows fonts over plain

rectangles. I didn&#39;t expect the game to 
occasionally freeze mid-combat for thirty

seconds to yell the word &quot;BULLSHIT&quot; and show us 
the enemy activating a pathetically ineffective

special attack in a highly cinematic and notably 
unskippable way. The core combat gives you a

choice of over two melee weapons. Three. There&#39;s 
THREE melee weapons. And you only unlock the

third one in, like, mission four. In contrast, 
the upgrade tree is quite extensive, and quite

expensive as well, so by the time I hit story end 
I&#39;d only unlocked, like six things out of thirty,

but encountered no difficulty whatsoever. &quot;Oh 
but you can replay the missions as many times

as you want with your friends to unlock all the 
extra upgrades and cosmetics!&quot; Hm, good point, I

do have too many friends. Oh, are you still here, 
South Park Snow Day? I don&#39;t know if you trying

to encourage replays makes me laugh or cringe 
more. Feels like I got to your birthday party

an hour late to find I&#39;m the only guest who showed 
up. Wait, that&#39;s a flawed analogy, &#39;cos birthday

parties are fun. Let&#39;s say I showed up just as 
you were pissing all over the sausage rolls.
